poem:
Title: A Morning on Donoussa

Elias, quiet as morning's lisp,
Directs us past the kafeneio's whisper.
The news, less significant than coffee,
Disappears in the alley's shrug.
Here, where houses gather like simple prayers
Rough bamboo and hewn logs cradle a view:
Men debate, but the sea, unassuming,
Does not argue its blue impartiality.
Can one, I venture, drive to such quietude? Not
In a car, but feet suffice.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Europe’s best beach holidays: Donoussa, Greece Elias, quiet and unassuming, meets us at the tiny harbour and says he could drive us to the house but it would be quicker on foot. He directs us up a narrow alley past a bustling kafeneio, where people are debating the news of the day over coffee. One of a little cluster of houses, ours has a pergola of rough-hewn logs and bamboo, and looks out to sea". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
